text: well one of the things I like to do most
is to get into an archive and look
or manuscripts particularly manuscripts
that people hadn't looked at in a very
long time things that might give me some
kind of insider's view on what the
characters I'm interested in learning
about we're really doing so one of the
things that I did some years ago was to
look at the papers of Robert Boyle
famous character we all learned Boyle's
law about gases one of the things that I
discovered in his papers was a huge
amount of work on trying to make the
Philosopher's Stone and transmute base
metals into gold the result of that was
I I wrote a book on on Boyle
of and his our chemical quest which
gives us now a very different view of
the famous English scientist shows him
more in his context and what he was
himself was really interested in doing
after that with my colleague at Indiana
University bill Newman we wrote together
a couple of books on an interesting
character by the name George Starkey and
his interactions with Boyle mostly
because we had come across some of his
laboratory notebooks everyone every
scientist nowadays takes laboratory
notebooks we don't think about it
happening for of alchemists looking for
the secret of transmutation working in
the 1650s but this fellow Starkey kept
beautiful laboratory notebooks so we
wrote a book about his notebooks and
then we transcribed the notebooks
translated them and published that as
well I I started out as a PhD chemist in
synthetic organic chemistry and I just
got more and more interested in the
history of science where ideas came from
how chemists came up with ideas you know
we do this all the time in the lab today
but how did people do it years ago I
mean in this in the 16th century where
did ideas come from how did they come
out of laboratory observations and so I
just gradually gravitated more and more
towards the historical aspect and now I
live a schizophrenic life between a
chemistry department where I teach and
the history of science and
technology Department where I also teach
I'm Larry pr√≠ncipe I'm professor of
chemistry and professor of history of
Science and Technology Johns Hopkins
University
